item.title: DealBook: Urenco, Powerhouse of the Uranium Enrichment Industry, Wants Out
item.description: Urenco, the global leader in its field, wants to sell for reasons of geopolitics, economics and the notion of an energy source that could turn deadly.
item.dc:creator: By STANLEY REED
item.media:description: Urenco, a European consortium, built a uranium enrichment plant in New Mexico.

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Leaders Create a Rapid-Reaction Force
item.description: African leaders said they would create a military force to deal with coups, rebellions and wars, seeking to reduce the continent’s reliance on foreign troops and funds.
item.category: African Capacity for Immediate Response to Crises
Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Britain: 10th Arrest in Hacking Death
item.description: The police said Monday that they had arrested a 10th suspect in the killing of an off-duty British soldier on a London street.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Myanmar: Concern Over 2-Child Limit
item.description: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, rights groups and Islamic leaders expressed dismay over plans in Rakhine State to revive a two-child limit on Muslim Rohingya families, a policy that does not apply to Buddhists.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Cambodia: Protest at Factory for Nike
item.description: At least 23 workers were hurt in Cambodia on Monday after the police clashed with workers protesting wages at a factory that makes clothing for Nike, a union representative said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Brazil: Mayor Punches Resident in Face
item.description: The mayor of Rio de Janeiro, Eduardo Paes, punched a constituent in the face after being called the Portuguese equivalent of “excrement” in a dispute at a restaurant.
item.dc:creator: By SIMON ROMERO

item.title: By Inserting Itself Into Syrian War, Hezbollah Makes Historic Gamble
item.description: Hezbollah is betting its prestige and security by taking its followers on an uncharted mission that could bring new power or end in defeat with wide repercussions.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ANNE BARNARD
item.media:description: Supporters of the Lebanese militant group Hezbollah and relatives of one of its fighters, Saleh Ahmed Sabagh, at his funeral last week in Sidon, Lebanon.

item.title: Europeans End Embargo, Opening Path to Arming Syrian Rebels
item.description: Though the European Union had no immediate plans to arm the fighters, an official said, the move provided “flexibility” for the future.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: A Free Syrian Army fighter in Deir al-Zour returned fire in a clash last week with forces loyal to President Bashar al-Assad.

item.title: King of Spain Gives Up Yacht, but Donors Want It Back
item.description: The businesspeople who gave the $27 million, 136-foot yacht to King Juan Carlos 13 years ago want him to return it rather than give it to the government.
item.category: Juan Carlos I, King of Spain
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Rome Journal: Same-Sex Couple Say, ‘I Do’ in Rome
item.description: The wedding of Massimiliano Benedetto and Giuseppe Ilaria in Rome last week was a symbolic step in a country that does not recognize same-sex unions of any kind.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO
item.media:credit: Marco Gualazzini for the International Herald Tribune
item.media:description: Massimiliano Benedetto, left, and Giuseppe Ilaria after the ceremony in Rome. “This is a celebration that’s outside the rules,” said Imma Battaglia, a prominent gay rights activist.

item.title: Pakistan Electricity Shortages Reach Crisis Stage
item.description: Electricity shortages — the product of decrepit power plants, corruption and policy mistakes that are decades old — have reached crisis proportions.
item.dc:creator: By DECLAN WALSH and SALMAN MASOOD
item.media:credit: Diego Ibarra Sanchez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A vendor in Lahore, Pakistan, during a power interruption. Lights go out for at least 10 hours a day in major cities, and up to 22 hours a day in rural areas.

item.title: At Least 53 Killed in Bombings in Iraq
item.description: The attacks in Shiite neighborhoods in Baghdad added to concerns about a renewal of the kind of sectarian violence that tore through the country in 2006 and 2007.
item.dc:creator: By DURAID ADNAN
item.media:description: The scene of a car bomb attack in a commercial area of central Baghdad on Monday.

item.title: The Caucus: McCain Travels to Syria to Meet With Anti-Assad Forces
item.description: Senator John McCain, who has called for the Obama administration to intervene militarily in Syria, was the first American senator to meet with the rebel fighters.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: Afghan TV Throws Spotlight on Abuse of Police Officers
item.description: A police officer’s on-air interview about a beating he suffered after stopping a military commander’s son has set off a chain of apologies and accusations.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED and HABIB ZAHORI

item.title: Ai Weiwei Dioramas Depict His Imprisonment
item.description: Dioramas by the Chinese artist Ai Weiwei, to be shown in Venice, reconstruct his illegal detention in China in minute detail.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG
item.media:credit: Cristiano Bendinelli for The New York Times
item.media:description: One of Ai Weiwei’s dioramas that recreate his harrowing experiences as a prisoner of the Chinese authorities.

item.title: More Than 70 Killed in Wave of Baghdad Bombings
item.description: More than a dozen blasts tore into markets and shopping areas across the Iraqi capital, in worsening sectarian violence.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS
item.media:description: The scene of a car bomb attack in a commercial area of central Baghdad on Monday.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: May 27
item.description: Sonia Gandhi, president of Congress Party, paid tribute to India’s first prime minister, Jawaharlal Nehru, on the 49th anniversary of his death.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Sonia Gandhi, president of the Congress party, third from left, with Sheila Dikshit, chief minister of Delhi, paying tribute on the 49th anniversary of the death of Jawaharlal Nehru, India's first prime minister, at his memorial in New Delhi.

item.title: At War Blog: The ‘Affectionate Burden’ Left by a Fallen Friend
item.description: A Marine found that honoring a friend killed in Afghanistan also meant honoring his own grief.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ZACHARY BELL
item.media:description: Lance Cpl. Philip Clark in Marja, Afghanistan, in April 2010.

item.title: India Ink: Only in Delhi is the Cocktail Dress a Uniform
item.description: Advice for the perpetually well-dressed Delhi women — sometimes too much can be, well, too much.
item.dc:creator: By SUJATA ASSOMULL SIPPY
item.media:credit: Manpreet Romana for The New York Times
item.media:description: Youngsters at a mall in New Delhi.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Cameron Criticized For Spanish Beachside Break
item.description: David Cameron, the British prime minister, is the latest politician to come under fire for taking a vacation at a time of crisis. Should leaders always be at their posts, or should we give them a break?
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: The Camerons on vacation in Ibiza on Sunday.

item.title: Osaka Mayor Reframes Comments on Wartime Brothels
item.description: The mayor of Osaka denied justifying the use of so-called comfort women by Japanese troops during World War II.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI

item.title: India Ink: Braving the Indian Heat
item.description: A glimpse of how people across India are trying to beat the heat.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Letter from Europe: Short of Skilled Hands, Germany Looks South
item.description: Propelled by high unemployment, thousands of educated graduates are immigrating to Germany from Southern Europe, but it still won't be enough to solve the country's long-term labor shortage.
item.dc:creator: By JUDY DEMPSEY

item.title: India Ink: Security Forces’ Fatalities on the Rise in Kashmir
item.description: Twice as many security force personnel have been killed as militants so far this year in the Kashmir Valley.
item.dc:creator: By BETWA SHARMA
item.media:description: Policemen tending to an injured colleague during a protest in Srinagar, Jammu and Kashmir, on Tuesday.

item.title: British Soldier’s Killer Had Ties to Al Qaeda, Government Says
item.description: Authorities said they knew that Michael Adebolajo, a suspect in the murder of an off-duty soldier last week, had been arrested in Kenya on suspicion of planning to join an extremist group.
item.dc:creator: By JOHN F. BURNS
